text: Isn't a problem with the current Julia Interpreter though that it really just has value in the context of debugging. Since the interpreter is written in Julia, you cannot quickly load it from the shell, say if you wanted to use Julia for quick Unix scripts and don't want to pay the price of the JIT lag. Although I suppose when the building of binaries from Julia code matures more, that may be a viable path to create a stand alone Julia interpreter.

text: I think that Julia will not benefit from an interpreter. Probably Rob is saying that because he thinks that the JIT is unnecessary because he is used to have everything compiled-AOT and just use python to glue things. However, I think that Julia would greatly benefit from having frozen libraries that are compiled-aot, especially the ones that rarely change. I know that this can be done via `PackageCompiler.jl`, but I am talking of having extension-like libraries with compiled-aot for common cases that I can optionally use or not, for example, loading `Plots.j` or `DataFrames.jl` compiled-aot when I am in _production_ mode and the regular ones when I am in _development_ mode

text: You don’t have to guess what I’m saying. You can just ask. I’m not sure why folks here insist on comparing everything to Python and assuming I am doing the same. I haven’t mentioned Python at all. This isn’t about Julia versus Python. It’s about Julia on its own merits. It’s not a zero sum game. Frankly the assumptions I see on here about my own programming background, level of expertise, and diversity of experience with different languages are borderline offensive. I am not a “Python developer” and don’t identify as such. I program competently a bunch of different languages and use different tools and techniques at different times as the problem demands. I’m not zealous about any particular technology, and try to take tools at face value.

text: I know it’s hard to remember what it’s like to first experience a new ecosystem and to have adjust your expectations and ways of working accordingly. You might think about whether fairly dismissive attitudes to my experiences will make me more likely to use Julia in the future, or less likely to use Julia in the future.  I’m investing my own money into evaluating Julia for serious work. Switching costs are high, often prohibitively so.  Introducing new languages is expensive and carries risk. I’m opening minded about whether Julia will prove successful in our project. You might consider the value of my opinions while I am at the neophyte stage before I become acclimatized to (or hostage to) the trade-offs inherent in the Julia language design.

text: The fact remains that on the last moderately sized system we built for designing chemical processing equipment, I could run over 2000 tests consisting of 16000 lines of test code in around 20 seconds (including unit tests, integration tests, many being property-based tests of 200 iterations each) in around 20 seconds. These tests covered 35000 lines of production code. In our nascent Julia system we have 306 lines of test code in 12 testsets and 108 lines of production code. The Julia tests take over 30 seconds to run. So yeah, forgive me if latency is a concern.

text:
Robert, neophytes experience is super valuable and no one says the current status is perfect, but please understand that writing a thread on twitter saying (quoting)

> maybe because testing isn't an important activity in #JuliaLang culture. Feels a bit out of time. Anachronistic.
> 
which is wildly untrue, isn't the best way to engage a community. Everyone using Julia, at all levels, is well aware of the shortcomings of compilation latency, and there is constant work to improve it (did you try using Julia in the 0.x times?) but we also try to adapt our workflows to minimise its impact, while being able to test our code (believe it or not, vast majority of users do test their code). Using the REPL and Revise is one of these simple changes.

Coming to the community sharing your experience and frustration is super useful (we even have a channel for this: <#C67TK21LJ|gripes>) and David came up with improvements in the vscode plugin in, what, a couple of hours? But telling the world unsubstantiated hypothesis is not nice

text: <@U01KDRNJULA> Thanks for joining! I agree that it is better to talk to you directly than guessing what you meant. I am also considering to use Julia for use on photo-lithography systems and other kind of control software related to that. So, I think that our concerns are aligned to some extent. Our production code is made in other languages like C++, C# and Java. Running tests for those takes a great deal of time, not sure about the numbers but about a couple of hours. However, for us the largest deal comes when transferring prototypes in MATLAB and python to production code, this usually takes very long time on the order of weeks sometimes months. So, I would rather not have longer testing times, but would be ok with it if that shortens the porting time or gets rid of it.
